10,000 PANTSMAKERS GO ON STRIKE TODAY. Men's Garment Workers to the Number of 70,000 May Quit Work on Wednesday. MOBILIZED FOR BIG FIGHT. Manufacturers Show Sympathy with Workers in Quarrel with Contractors.
July 12, 1915
With a Council of Conciliation to meet tomorrow in an attempt to adjust the quarrels of the 60,000 women's garment workers in the city and their employers, the 80,000 men's garment workers yesterday completed plans they have been making for six weeks for a general strike.

comment._content: This is taken from an upper story window near 62 Essex Street, at the corner of Essex Market Place, a street which was closed in 1926 which ran between Essex and Ludlow, on the block between Grand and Broome. Coincidentally, the photo 2 in front of this one in the news stream was taken at the other end of Essex Market Place, at the Ludlow corner, in front of the Ludlow Street Jail. The buildings on both sides of this block have been demolished since this photo was taken. The building on the northeast corner of Essex and Broome, just visible in back of the wagon at the very top under the word July, is still there. The details of the spirited conversations, pushcart vendors and street life on the Lower East Side in general are well captured. It's not unlikely that the same photographer took both photos on the same day. This picture is wonderful in the highest resolution at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.19510 . The view from the approximate location, at street level, in July, 2011: maps.google.com/maps?q=62+essex+street,+nyc&ll=40.716...
